overview: Daniel contains both narrative and apocalyptic prophecy. Daniel's faithfulness in Babylon's courts and his visions of coming kingdoms encourage God's people to remain faithful while awaiting God's ultimate victory.

verses.text: If this be so, our God whom we serve is able to deliver us from the burning fiery furnace, and he will deliver us out of your hand, O king. But if not, be it known to you, O king, that we will not serve your gods.
He changes times and seasons; he removes kings and sets up kings; he gives wisdom to the wise and knowledge to those who have understanding.
My God sent his angel and shut the lions' mouths, and they have not harmed me, because I was found blameless before him.

passages.title: The Fiery Furnace
passages.summary: Three young men refuse to bow to Nebuchadnezzar's idol and are thrown into a furnace, but God delivers them and a fourth figure appears.

passages.title: Daniel in the Lions' Den
passages.summary: Daniel continues praying to God despite a royal decree. He's thrown to lions, but God shuts their mouths.

passages.title: The Son of Man
passages.summary: Daniel sees 'one like a son of man' approaching God's throne and receiving eternal dominion—a key messianic prophecy.

facts.text: Jesus' favorite self-designation 'Son of Man' comes from Daniel 7:13, a clearly divine figure.
Daniel's prophecy of 70 'weeks' (Daniel 9:24-27) is one of the most studied prophecies, believed by many to predict Christ's timing.
Daniel served in Babylon's government from Nebuchadnezzar through Cyrus—about 70 years of faithful service.
The book was written partly in Hebrew and partly in Aramaic (the international language of the time).

figures.name: Daniel
figures.description: A young exile who rose to prominence in Babylon while maintaining unwavering faithfulness to God through multiple regimes.

figures.name: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego
figures.description: Daniel's three friends who refused to bow to the king's idol and were miraculously delivered from the fiery furnace.

figures.name: Nebuchadnezzar
figures.description: Babylon's greatest king who conquered Jerusalem but eventually acknowledged Daniel's God as the Most High.

videos.title: Daniel Overview
videos.description: The Bible Project explores Daniel's stories of faithfulness and visions of God's kingdom.
